channel.title: BBC Sport

item.title: 'Tuchel and England's world will not revolve around Bellingham'
item.description: Jude Bellingham still has a point to prove despite being recalled to Thomas Tuchel's England squad, says chief football writer Phil McNulty.

item.title: From non-league to England call-up - who is 'Guernsey Grealish' Scott?
item.description: From the eighth tier of English football to the England squad - who is new Three Lions call-up Alex Scott?

item.title: 'Arsenal attack like 'Invincibles' and defend like class of 97-98'
item.description: They have won nothing yet, but this Arsenal side reminds me of the ones I won three league titles with, writes Martin Keown.

item.title: Guardiola in disbelief at numbers before 1,000th game
item.description: Pep Guardiola says he can't believe the numbers he has achieved before taking charge of his 1,000th game in management when Manchester City host Liverpool in the Premier League on Sunday.

item.title: Will Arsenal be team to end Chelsea's 'ridiculous' unbeaten run?
item.description: Chelsea haven't lost a match in the Women's Super League in 32 games, but could Arsenal be the team to finally end that record?

item.title: Osmajic gets nine-game ban for racially abusing Hannibal
item.description: Preston forward Milutin Osmajic is given a nine-game ban after being charged with racially abusing Burnley midfielder Hannibal Mejbri.

item.title: Barton guilty over 'grossly offensive' X posts
item.description: The former footballer directed posts on X towards Jeremy Vine and pundits Lucy Ward and Eni Aluko.

item.title: Tuchel 'delighted' over Bellingham and Foden return
item.description: England manager Thomas Tuchel has backed midfielders Phil Foden and Jude Bellingham following their return to the squad for games against Serbia and Albania.

item.title: 'You can't make this up' - Robins v Lampard one year on
item.description: A year on from being sacked by Coventry City, Mark Robins faces his old club as Stoke City take on the Sky Blues in a top-of-the-Championship blockbuster.

item.title: Maccabi fan ban was due to hooliganism, say police
item.description: West Midlands Police did not previously reveal its reasons because "it wasn't deemed helpful".

item.title: Maresca defends rotation after Rooney criticism
item.description: Chelsea manager Enzo Maresca defends his rotation policy after criticism from former England captain Wayne Rooney.

item.title: Amorim wins manager of month award for October
item.description: Manchester United boss Ruben Amorim wins the Premier League manager of the month award for October as he is awarded the prize for the first time.

item.title: Areola on dogs, pressure and West Ham fighting back
item.description: West Ham United goalkeeper Alphonse Areola joins BBC Sport's Betty Glover for a dog walk to talk about the Hammers' tough run of form and his love of dogs.

item.title: 'We are changing things' - Amorim responds to Ronaldo comments
item.description: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim has urged the club to "look forward" rather than "dwell on the past" after comments from Cristiano Ronaldo in which the former United player criticised the club, adding Amorin could not work "miracles".

item.title: 'I used to stage fights' - Man City confessions
item.description: Manchester City players including Khadija 'Bunny' Shaw and Lauren Hemp share their confessions including things they got away with growing up, mid-game thoughts and what football rule they would change.

item.title: Guardiola praises Foden after Man City win
item.description: Manager Pep Guardiola likes what he sees from his Manchester City side as they beat Borussia Dortmund 4-1 in the Champions League with Phil Foden scoring two goals.

item.title: The Premier League is the best in the world - Pochettino
item.description: Former Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino tells BBC Sport that he is "missing" the Premier League and would like to return in the future.

item.title: Sutton's predictions v Bath & England rugby star Ollie Lawrence
item.description: BBC Sport football expert Chris Sutton takes on Bath and England rugby star Ollie Lawrence with his predictions for this weekend's Premier League fixtures.

item.title: Five things to look out for in EFL: Old faces, new places
item.description: Five things to keep an eye on in the EFL this weekend, including managers facing their old team, promoted sides finding their feet and bosses under pressure.

item.title: 'Immense' Bellingham and Foden recalled by England
item.description: Thomas Tuchel also hands a first call-up to Bournemouth midfielder Alex Scott, with England having already qualified for the World Cup.

item.title: 'Trailblazer' Blundell wants to inspire other mothers
item.description: Manchester United defender Hannah Blundell says she feels like a "trailblazer" returning seven months after giving birth - and encourages more sportswomen to follow her lead.

item.title: Referees among suspects sought in match-fixing probe
item.description: Turkish prosecutors issue detention orders for 21 people - including 17 referees and two club presidents - as part of a major investigation into betting and match fixing.

item.title: Baffling? Distracting? The fallout from Earps' book
item.description: Mary Earps' comments in her autobiography have caused a stir but what has the fallout been?

item.title: 'I am doing OK. I have my moments... I have lost my daughter'
item.description: Greenock Morton manager Dougie Imrie tells BBC Scotland about the loss he feels after losing his baby daughter and the support shown him by the Scottish football community.

item.title: All your FPL stats and Premier League team news in one place
item.description: Every key bit of Premier League team news and the most important Fantasy Premier League statistics - all in one place.

item.title: Norwich announce loss of £20.7m in 2024-25
item.description: Norwich City announce a £20.7m loss for the 12 months to the end of June as the team continues to struggle near the foot of the Championship.

item.title: New Rangers dawn as far away as ever in European Groundhog Day
item.description: Rangers' resurrection under new regime still feels a pipe dream after latest European defeat, writes BBC Scotland's Scott Mullen.

item.title: BBC to show Boreham Wood and Sutton FA Cup ties
item.description: The BBC will broadcast ties between Boreham Wood and Newport County and Sutton United v Shrewsbury Town in the FA Cup second round.

item.title: How Leicester are tackling mental health issues with goals
item.description: BBC Sport takes a look at how one of Leicester City's community projects is helping people deal with mental health issues though football.

item.title: Why Zohran Mamdani owns shares in a Spanish football club
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explains why New York City's newly elected mayor owns a share in a Spanish football club.

item.title: 'Edge' between Wrexham and Charlton - Parkinson
item.description: Phil Parkinson admits there is an "edge" between Wrexham and Charlton Athletic as a result of the battles they had in League One last season.

item.title: Tottenham eye move for Toney - Friday's gossip
item.description: Ivan Toney could be offered a route back to England with Tottenham, Real Madrid are keeping tabs on Declan Rice, and Chelsea enquire about Nico Paz.

item.title: Should you triple up on Arsenal defenders? The FPL talking point
item.description: Expert FPL Holly Shand and the guys from the FPL Podcast by BBC Sport debate this week's FPL talking point.

item.title: Ainsworth 'fixed & ready to go' after heart surgery
item.description: Gillingham boss Gareth Ainsworth says that he is now "fixed and ready to go" after heart surgery.

item.title: Middlesbrough reject Wolves approach for Edwards
item.description: Middlesbrough reject Wolves' request to speak to their boss Rob Edwards about the Premier League side's vacant head coach role.

item.title: Arrests as hundreds protest at Villa-Maccabi match
item.description: Eleven men are held amid a huge police operation near Villa Park involving 700 officers.

item.title: Can Man Utd shore up defence without losing their cutting edge?
item.description: Manchester United's matches have had more goals than any other Premier League side this season, but can they tighten up at the back while still scoring freely?

item.title: 'Teacher' O'Neill with work to do as Celtic taught another lesson
item.description: Interim Celtic manager cut an exasperated figure in Denmark as he watched a magnificent Midtjylland teach the Scottish champions a lesson.

item.title: Captain Joao Pedro over Haaland - FPL team of the week
item.description: With Chelsea facing managerless Wolves at home this week, it's a chance for FPL managers to captain someone other than Erling Haaland.

item.title: How to follow the Premier League on the BBC this weekend
item.description: BBC Sport Ask Me Anything explains how to follow the Premier League on the BBC this weekend.

item.title: 'Flying' Sarr easing Crystal Palace's Eze loss
item.description: Ismaila Sarr shines as Crystal Palace earn first home victory in Europa Conference League this term.

item.title: Lockyer on emotion of Rovers return and Wales dream
item.description: Bristol Rovers defender Tom Lockyer says he felt emotional about stepping back onto the football pitch after two years out and dreams of playing for Wales again.

item.title: Sale could revolutionise Sheff Wed - administrator
item.description: Some of the parties interested in buying Sheffield Wednesday have "significant financial means" that could "revolutionise" the troubled club, says a joint administrator.

item.title: Tonali 'happy' but says future hard to predict
item.description: Newcastle United midfielder Sandro Tonali says he is taking his future at the club "year-for-year" but is "happy" with the Magpies.

item.title: Man Utd made mistakes - Amorim on Ronaldo criticism
item.description: Manchester United boss Ruben Amorim admits the club "made a lot of mistakes in the past" when addressing criticism from ex-player Cristiano Ronaldo.

item.title: Ajax to sack former Liverpool coach Heitinga
item.description: Ajax have sacked manager John Heitinga after 15 matches and less than six months after he joined the club from Liverpool.

item.title: Earps reaction 'shows pressure on women to be perfect angels'
item.description: In her latest column, Anita Asante looks at how we react to role models not conforming in women's football and the fallout from Mary Earps' book.

item.title: 'If a player was recommended, I always watched them twice away from home'
item.description: In his BBC Sport column, Tony Pulis looks at the increase in data in recruitment, sports science and medicine in football and examines whether it helps managers or not.

item.title: Who do fans think is the key player in each Premier League team?
item.description: From the "soul of the team" to an "absolute warrior", here are the Premier League's 20 key players, as chosen by our fan writers.

item.title: San Siro to be demolished - can Milan clubs compete with Premier League?
item.description: The two Milan football clubs announce plans to demolish San Siro and build a new stadium - but they can they claw the back the gap with English clubs?

item.title: Identity, belonging, defiantly local - inside Athletic Club's success
item.description: BBC Sport examines how Athletic Club continue to be one of Spain's most successful teams despite their unique selection policy.

item.title: Transfers - September to December 2025
item.description: Check out the significant signings and departures in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, EFL and Women's Super League.

item.title: Manager ins and outs - 2025-26 season
item.description: BBC Sport tracks all the manager ins and outs in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, Women's Super League, English Football League and National League.

item.title: Why can Channel Islands players play for England?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team look at why players born in the Channel Islands like Alex Scott can represent England at a senior level.

item.title: What are the Fifa Best Awards?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain what the Fifa Best Awards are, who can vote and who the nominees are.

item.title: Why do footballers tape up their wrists?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explains why footballers use tape to wrap their wrists.

item.title: Who are the youngest Champions League players?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team looks at the youngest players have ever played in the Champions League

item.title: What is a ghostwriter after Earps' book backlash?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team look at what it means when a book is ghostwritten.

item.title: Where are England's U17 World Cup winners now?
item.description: Ever wondered what happened to England's U17 World Cup-winning side from 2017? BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains...

item.title: 'I tapped him' - Trusty responds to Butland concerns
item.description: Rangers' Jack Butland finds it "difficult to accept" the decision not to send off Auston Trusty in Sunday's Scottish League Cup semi-final, while the Celtic defender insists he merely "tapped" the goalkeeper.

item.title: Can Hearts ramp up pressure? Eyes on Congreve & Askou
item.description: Another look at what's in store over the weekend in the Scottish Premiership.

item.title: Head coach Vieira leaves bottom club Genoa
item.description: Patrick Vieira leaves his role as Genoa head coach by mutual consent after they fail to win in nine Serie A games this season.

item.title: Vinicius Jr no longer feels 'untouchable' - so what's going on?
item.description: Vinicius Jr no longer feels untouchable at Real Madrid and recent events are a truce, not a resolution, writes Guillem Balague.

item.title: Juventus appoint former Italy manager Spalletti
item.description: Juventus appoint former Italy head coach Luciano Spalletti as their manager until the end of the season.

item.title: 149 Turkish officials suspended in betting probe
item.description: The Turkish Football Federation (TFF) suspends 149 referees and assistant referees for allegedly betting on matches.

item.title: PSG's Doue out 'for a few weeks' with thigh injury
item.description: Forward Desire Doue has injured his right thigh and will be "unavailable for a few weeks", Paris St-Germain confirm.

item.title: Real seek 'substantial damages' over Super League ruling
item.description: Real Madrid will seek "substantial damages" from Uefa after European football's governing body lost a court appeal over the failed European Super League.

item.title: Man dies after wheelchair collides with car driven by Inter keeper
item.description: A man dies after his electric wheelchair collides with a car driven by Inter Milan goalkeeper Josep Martinez.

item.title: Northern Ireland captain Magill announces pregnancy
item.description: Northern Ireland captain and Birmingham City striker Simone Magill announces she is pregnant and will sit out the rest of the season.

item.title: England drawn with Spain in World Cup qualifying
item.description: England are drawn with Spain in their qualifying group for the 2027 Women's World Cup as Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and Republic of Ireland all learn their opponents.

item.title: From farming village to Liverpool icon - the Salah story
item.description: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

item.title: Napoli 'smell blood' & target Premier League's discarded stars
item.description: After Scott McTominay was a hit, Napoli went back to the Premier League for Kevin de Bruyne, could more players follow them to Serie A?

item.title: How does Daniel Levy run Tottenham - and would he ever leave?
item.description: With Tottenham struggling on the pitch and chairman Daniel Levy facing criticism from fans, BBC Sport looks at how the club is run and what the future might hold.

item.title: When River Plate icon Diaz took over fourth-tier Oxford
item.description: Twenty years on from Ramon Diaz's surprising appointment at Oxford United, BBC Sport looks at what happened and how it went.

item.title: East meets west London - the mentor who changed Chelsea
item.description: Vinay Menon knew nothing about football when he went for a meeting at a west London mansion in 2009. A few weeks later he was in the heart of the Chelsea dressing room.

item.title: The air crash and the underdogs - a triumph for a lost generation
item.description: Nineteen years and 10 miles separated Zambia's football team from a lost, golden generation on a fateful night in Libreville.

item.title: The rise and fall of North Korea - the sleeping giant of women's football
item.description: North Korea lags behind most of the rest of the world in several areas. But the hermit state has had an outsized impact on international women's football.
